articles.headline: Falling Gas Prices Deny Russia a Lever of Power
articles.snippet: Seeking a monopoly on gas supplies, Gazprom committed to long-term contracts at costs far above current prices.
articles.abstract: Seeking a monopoly on gas supplies, Gazprom committed to long-term contracts at costs far above current prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  As energy markets shrink, the same tactics that the Kremlin used to build Gazprom, the giant energy company, into a fearsome economic and political power that could restore Russian influence in the world are now backfiring, slashing both its profits and its influence.

articles.headline: Geffen Is Seen as Still Eager for Times Stake
articles.snippet: People familiar with David Geffen’s thinking say the media mogul is willing to wait for his chance to buy a sizable piece of the company or even take it over completely.
articles.abstract: People familiar with David Geffen’s thinking say the media mogul is willing to wait for his chance to buy a sizable piece of the company or even take it over completely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite falling short in two recent attempts to become a major player in The New York Times Company, David Geffen continues to be seriously interested in buying a sizable piece of the company or taking it over completely, according to people who are very familiar with his thinking, though he is wary of doing anything to antagonize the controlling Sulzberger family.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Work Halted on Helicopter for President
articles.snippet: Pentagon officials stopped work on a costly new helicopter despite efforts by the contractors and their supporters in Congress to salvage part of the project.
articles.abstract: Pentagon officials stopped work on a costly new helicopter despite efforts by the contractors and their supporters in Congress to salvage part of the project.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pentagon officials on Friday stopped work on a costly new presidential helicopter despite efforts by the contractors and their supporters in Congress to salvage part of the project.

articles.headline: Conservatives Map Strategies on Court Fight
articles.snippet: Preparing to oppose the confirmation of President Obama’s eventual choice to succeed Justice David H. Souter, conservative groups are working together to stockpile ammunition.
articles.abstract: Preparing to oppose the confirmation of President Obama’s eventual choice to succeed Justice David H. Souter, conservative groups are working together to stockpile ammunition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  If President Obama nominates Judge Diane P. Wood to the Supreme Court, conservatives plan to attack her as an “outspoken” supporter of “abortion, including partial-birth abortion.”

articles.headline: Even to Save Cash, Don’t Try This Stuff at Home
articles.snippet: A new class of ambitious do-it-yourselfers has learned that being thrifty can sometimes come at a high price.
articles.abstract: A new class of ambitious do-it-yourselfers has learned that being thrifty can sometimes come at a high price.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Saving money never cost quite so much.

articles.headline: From Frisée to Finance, It Has to Be Perfect
articles.snippet: Daniel Boulud is opening DBGB on the Lower East Side, dipping a toe into more casual fare just as high-end restaurants have been devastated.
articles.abstract: Daniel Boulud is opening DBGB on the Lower East Side, dipping a toe into more casual fare just as high-end restaurants have been devastated.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the middle of the kitchen at Daniel, a four-star restaurant on the Upper East Side, a set of steep stairs leads to a cozy little nook known as the skybox. It has one lacquered-wood table, room for four diners, a television and two large windows overlooking the action below. The space feels like the eating quarters of a yacht set in a tree house.

articles.headline: When a Company Tries It, a ‘Say on Pay’ Works
articles.snippet: One executive called up big shareholders to sound them out on pay he received.
articles.abstract: One executive called up big shareholders to sound them out on pay he received.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISOLATED and imperial chief executives who shun contact with the great unwashed  shareholders who actually own the companies  are a distressingly resilient breed.

articles.headline: NBC Hired a Hit Maker. It’s Still Waiting.
articles.snippet: Ben Silverman came to the network two years ago as a rising star with an eye on a turnaround, but there have been stumbles.
articles.abstract: Ben Silverman came to the network two years ago as a rising star with an eye on a turnaround, but there have been stumbles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN NBC hired Ben Silverman in May 2007, he was the hottest executive in the television business, the man who had a hand in bringing reality shows and “The Office” to America. He also happened to be taking a job he had dreamed about as a junior high schooler hooked on television: the top programmer position at NBC.

articles.headline: From a Theory to a Consensus on Emissions
articles.snippet: Cap and trade, hatched as a theory in obscure economic journals, has become the policy of choice in the debate over how to slow the heating of the planet.
articles.abstract: Cap and trade, hatched as a theory in obscure economic journals, has become the policy of choice in the debate over how to slow the heating of the planet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Congress weighs imposing a mandatory limit on climate-altering gases  an outcome still far from certain  it is likely to turn to a system that sets a government ceiling on total emissions and allows polluting industries to buy and sell permits to meet it.

articles.headline: Rebels Routed in Sri Lanka After 25 Years of War
articles.snippet: The ethnic Tamil separatist rebels of Sri Lanka acknowledged Sunday that their war of over a quarter century for a homeland had “reached its bitter end.”
articles.abstract: The ethnic Tamil separatist rebels of Sri Lanka acknowledged Sunday that their war of over a quarter century for a homeland had “reached its bitter end.”
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  The ethnic Tamil separatist rebels of Sri Lanka, one of the world’s most feared and enduring guerrilla movements, acknowledged Sunday that their war of more than a quarter-century for a homeland had “reached its bitter end.”
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Seth Mydans

articles.headline: At Notre Dame, Obama Calls for Civil Tone in Abortion Debate
articles.snippet: President Obama confronted America’s deep divide over abortion in an address that was protested by anti-abortion leaders.
articles.abstract: President Obama confronted America’s deep divide over abortion in an address that was protested by anti-abortion leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  President Obama directly confronted America’s deep divide over abortion on Sunday as he appealed to partisans on each side to find ways to respect one another’s basic decency and even work together to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: The Times and the Future
articles.snippet: Lately, when I finish an interview, most subjects ask about the newspaper’s future. So I thought I’d take a crack at the question.
articles.abstract: Lately, when I finish an interview, most subjects ask about the newspaper’s future. So I thought I’d take a crack at the question.
articles.lead_paragraph: Write about the media long enough and eventually you type your way to your own doorstep. Lately, when I finish an interview, most subjects have a question of their own.

articles.headline: For Wired, a Revival Lacks Ads
articles.snippet: The magazine’s editor has yet to figure out how to make the business as profitable as it is popular.
articles.abstract: The magazine’s editor has yet to figure out how to make the business as profitable as it is popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Anderson, the editor in chief of Wired, believes in logic the way Tina Brown believes in buzz. He rarely approves a story idea unless the writer backs up the thesis with data. The basis of his best-selling book “The Long Tail” was a statistical phenomenon called the Pareto distribution; in his coming book, “Free,” he expresses arguments in profit-loss charts. The walls in his San Francisco office are whiteboards, covered with scrawled formulas.

articles.headline: In Slump, Networks Scramble Lineups
articles.snippet: Estimates are that sales on the five big broadcast networks could decline by as much as 15 percent from last spring.
articles.abstract: Estimates are that sales on the five big broadcast networks could decline by as much as 15 percent from last spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each May, the big broadcast television networks invite advertisers, agency executives and affiliates to peek at their schedules for the coming season. But the awful economy threatens to spoil the party before it begins on Monday.
articles.byline: By Stuart Elliott and Bill Carter

articles.headline: New Mood in Antitrust May Target Google
articles.snippet: In the more aggressive antitrust climate of the Obama administration, the stakes appear to be highest for Google.
articles.abstract: In the more aggressive antitrust climate of the Obama administration, the stakes appear to be highest for Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the nation’s biggest antitrust cases have centered on technology companies. And they have all been efforts by the government to deal with powerful companies with far-reaching influence, like AT&T, the telephone monopoly; I.B.M., the mainframe computer giant; and Microsoft, the powerhouse of personal computer software.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Cellphone Makers Hope for a Blockbuster Summer
articles.snippet: The Palm Pre, an updated iPhone and new phones using the Android operating system are arriving this summer.
articles.abstract: The Palm Pre, an updated iPhone and new phones using the Android operating system are arriving this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hype machine started months ago. Opening weekends are upon us. High up in executive suites, the hope is that this summer’s new releases will cause lines to snake around the block.

articles.headline: Pakistan Is Rapidly Adding Nuclear Arms, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: There are new concerns on Capitol Hill about whether billions of dollars in proposed military aid might be diverted to Pakistan’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: There are new concerns on Capitol Hill about whether billions of dollars in proposed military aid might be diverted to Pakistan’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress have been told in confidential briefings that Pakistan is rapidly adding to its nuclear arsenal even while racked by insurgency, raising questions on Capitol Hill about whether billions of dollars in proposed military aid might be diverted to Pakistan’s nuclear program.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Prosecutors Block Access to DNA Testing for Inmates
articles.snippet: Prosecutors’ resistance to reopening cases is causing years of delay, sometimes eliminating the chance to try other suspects.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors’ resistance to reopening cases is causing years of delay, sometimes eliminating the chance to try other suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an age of advanced forensic science, the first step toward ending Kenneth Reed’s prolonged series of legal appeals should be simple and quick: a DNA test, for which he has offered to pay, on evidence from the 1991 rape of which he was convicted.
